sec.p:
In the northern high latitudes, one of the regions thought to be highly vulnerable to environmental change is the Canadian Arctic Archipelago (CAA), which contains the greatest area of global land ice outside the ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica (
1 ). With a glaciated area of ~146,000 km 2, the CAA has the potential to contribute 199 ± 30 mm to global mean sea level rise (
2 ). Rates of ice mass loss from the CAA have increased sharply during the 21st century (
3 –
6 ), from the Queen Elizabeth Islands (QEI) in the north [31 ± 8 gigatons (Gt) year −1 in 2004–2006, increasing to 92 ± 12 Gt year −1 in 2007–2009] (
3 ) to Baffin and Bylot Islands (BBI) further south (from 11.1 ± 3.4 Gt year −1 in 1963–2006 to 23.8 ± 6.12 Gt year −1 in 2003–2011) (
7 ). Although total ice mass loss is known, changes in individual glaciers have not been analyzed regionally.
